importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the game in which Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance, marking the Dodgers' clinching of the NLCS and advancement to the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The specific night of the game where Ohtani achieved a record-setting performance, culminating in a 5-1 victory over the Brewers and the Dodgers' sweep of the NLCS.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in Game 4 of the NLCS, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game.
Ohtani's performance included the first leadoff home run by a pitcher in MLB history, a 469-foot homer that cleared a pavilion roof, and a third solo shot in the seventh inning.
The Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, becoming only the fifth team to do so and the first to sweep an NLCS since Washington in 2019.
This performance made Ohtani the NLCS MVP, and he is widely considered to have delivered one of the greatest individual postseason games in baseball history.
The Dodgers are now headed to the World Series for the 23rd time in franchise history, with a chance to become the first repeat champions since the Yankees from 1998–2000.
The Brewers, who led the majors with 97 wins during the season, were eliminated for the third time in their recent playoff run and have not made a World Series appearance since 1982.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Japanese-American professional baseball player and three-time MVP, known for playing both as a pitcher and a hitter.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani delivered an unprecedented performance in the NLCS, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters, becoming the NLCS MVP and setting a record for individual performance in a postseason game.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles, known for its historic playoff success and frequent World Series appearances.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, clinching a spot in the World Series and achieving a historic first sweep of the NLCS since 2019.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team based in Milwaukee, known for having a strong regular-season record and frequent playoff appearances.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were swept in the NLCS by the Dodgers, marking their third elimination in recent playoff runs and their first World Series appearance since 1982.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, known for his leadership and strategic decisions in high-stakes games.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts praised Ohtani's performance as one of the greatest postseason performances in history and highlighted the team's momentum leading into the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A former World Series MVP and key player for the Dodgers, known for his defensive and offensive contributions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman praised Ohtani's performance as 'absolutely incredible' and described the moment as one that would be remembered as legendary.

namedEntities.name: Jose Quintana
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers, who started the game against Ohtani.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Quintana was the pitcher who allowed Ohtani's first leadoff homer, a milestone in MLB history as the first leadoff home run by a pitcher.

namedEntities.name: Roki Sasaki
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rookie relief pitcher for the Dodgers, who pitched the ninth inning in the NLCS win.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sasaki completed the game in relief, marking his first successful appearance as a closer in a postseason game.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A star outfielder and former World Series champion with the Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts contributed offensively with a single and a run in the first inning, helping establish early scoring for the Dodgers.

namedEntities.name: Will Smith
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dodgers player who contributed to the team's early scoring with a single and a run.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Smith provided key offensive support in the first inning, contributing to the Dodgers' early lead.

namedEntities.name: Jackson Chourio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Milwaukee Brewers player who got his first hit in the fourth inning.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chourio’s single was the first hit of the game for Milwaukee, but was stranded by Ohtani’s defensive and offensive dominance.

namedEntities.name: Blake Perkins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Brewers outfielder who commented on the team’s performance after the loss.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Perkins acknowledged that the team's offense struggled and attributed part of their loss to poor hitting and defensive lapses.

namedEntities.name: Pat Murphy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, who praised Ohtani’s performance despite the loss.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Murphy acknowledged Ohtani’s performance as possibly the best individual game in postseason history, showing respect for the magnitude of the achievement.

namedEntities.name: Alex Vesia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dodgers pitcher who escaped a late-inning jam.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vesia preserved the lead by escaping a critical situation in the seventh inning, allowing Ohtani to celebrate with his third home run.

namedEntities.name: Caleb Durbin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dodgers reliever who allowed a run in the eighth inning.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Durbin’s play allowed a run to score, but the Dodgers' overall dominance minimized the damage.

namedEntities.name: Brice Turang
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Milwaukee player who reached base on a grounder in the eighth inning.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Turang’s hit allowed a run to score, showing that Milwaukee still had some offensive capabilities despite the loss.

namedEntities.name: Anthony Banda
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Milwaukee player who ended the eighth inning with a crucial play.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Banda’s play ended the inning, showing the Brewers' bullpen struggled to contain the Dodgers’ offense.

namedEntities.name: New York Yankees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team known for winning three straight World Series from 1998 to 2000.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Yankees are cited as the only team to have achieved a repeat World Series title since the Dodgers' potential repeat attempt.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that played the Seattle Mariners in the ALCS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are in the ALCS, with the Mariners holding a 3-2 lead, creating a broader context for the postseason landscape.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that faced the Blue Jays in the ALCS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners advanced to the ALCS, creating a broader playoff picture where the Dodgers face either the Mariners or the Blue Jays in the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Philadelphia Phillies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball team that won back-to-back pennants in 2009.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Phillies are cited as the first team to win back-to-back pennants since, highlighting the rarity of the Dodgers’ achievement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a legendary two-way performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout ball into the seventh inning. The performance helped the Los Angeles Dodgers sweep the Milwaukee Brewers 5-1, marking the first NLCS sweep since Washington in 2019 and the first to sweep an NLCS since 2022. Ohtani was named NLCS MVP, and the Dodgers advance to the World Series for the 23rd time, with a chance to become the first repeat champions since the Yankees in 1998–2000. The Brewers, who had a 97-win regular season, were eliminated for the third time in their recent playoff run and have not made a World Series appearance since 1982. The game is widely regarded as one of the greatest individual performances in postseason history.
title: Shohei Ohtani hits 3 homers and strikes out 10 in Dodgers' clinching 5-1 NLCS win over Brewers
